unnormalised: ## The IT Scene in India: A Rapidly Changing Landscape
normalised: ## the I-T Scene in India: A Rapidly Changing Landscape

unnormalised: The IT sector in India has transformed significantly in recent years. It's no longer just about BPO and call centers. From startups disrupting the fintech space to established companies embracing cloud computing, the opportunities are immense. The sector currently contributes ~7.4% to India's GDP and is projected to grow even further. That’s quite a jump from even a decade ago.
normalised: the I-T sector in India has transformed significantly in recent years. it's no longer just about B-P-O and call centers. from startups disrupting the fintech space to established companies embracing cloud computing, the opportunities are immense. the sector currently contributes approximately seven point four percent to India's G-D-P and is projected to grow even further. that’s quite a jump from even a decade ago.

unnormalised: One of the biggest trends right now is the rise of AI and machine learning. Companies are scrambling to hire data scientists and ML engineers. Demand is soaring, and salaries are reflecting this. A quick search on Naukri.com will show you numerous openings with packages exceeding ₹30 LPA for experienced professionals. The talent pool is growing, but the demand is outpacing the supply. It is really a good time to get some skills.

unnormalised: Another key area is cybersecurity. With the increase in cyberattacks globally, businesses are investing heavily in protecting their data. Expect to see more companies hiring cybersecurity experts. CEH certification is becoming increasingly valuable, and ethical hacking is no longer a niche skill, but a must-have for many IT professionals. With more reliance on cloud solutions, this area is extremely important.

unnormalised: Cloud computing remains a major force. AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud are battling it out for market share in India. Most businesses are shifting their IT infrastructure to the cloud, and this trend is expected to continue. The demand for cloud architects and cloud engineers is at an all time high, and frankly, it is not looking like it will cool down anytime soon.

unnormalised: The startup ecosystem is thriving. Unicorns are popping up every month. Bangalore, often called the "Silicon Valley of India," remains the hotbed for startups, followed by Delhi and Mumbai. Funding is pouring in from both domestic and international investors. You can easily track this by following articles on sites like YourStory.

unnormalised: Looking ahead, the IT sector is expected to maintain its rapid growth trajectory. The government is investing heavily in digital infrastructure, and initiatives like Digital India are creating new opportunities. The next few years promise to be exciting times for IT professionals. Make sure you’re prepared to grab them.
